Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme

On Jan 3, 2012, at 10:54 AM, Mike Kelly wrote:

> There's nothing inherent=
ly wrong about statements like "the semantics
> of POST requests vary for d=
ifferent resources".

See, this is where you get it wrong. The semantics of=
 the request are always the same. The is no shared understanding that the s=
erver needs to know about. The server only receives a 'process this' reques=
t and the target resource will process the request entity. The server does =
not need to care about anything else.

The client develops an expectation (=
from previous hypermedia) about the effect of the POST request, but that ex=
pectation is just that: an expectation. And it might fail anytime.

Talking=
 about 'shared understanding' or 'varying semantics of POST requests' impli=
es that there are application level semantics on top of HTTP. There are not=
, HTTP is all the contract there is.



> The key is that those
> varying s=
emantics are _not visible_ on the network and are derived
> only from the s=
hared understanding between client and server. That's
> not a violation of =
REST constraints or the HTTP spec, it's a small
> clarification.

HTTP is n=
ot 'the network' (transport) it is an application protocol (transfer) and t=
here are no application semantics layered on top. (Except when you treat HT=
TP as transfer, of course. As WS-* does)

What you are getting wrong, I thi=
nk, is who knows about the particular applications being executed. You seem=
 to think that server and client have a shared understanding about the appl=
ication (e.g. buying a book at Amazon). They do not. Knowledge about the ap=
plication in a RESTful system is only located on the client. The server has=
 no idea what application a client is progressing through when it sends tha=
t POST. The POST means just this 'process this' and the given target resour=
ce will act on the POST as it sees fit.

The client then processes the resp=
onse with expectations originating from the application the client is in. T=
he server knows nor shares absolutely nothing about these expectations and =
has no obligation other than to 'process this'.

--

The hypermedia you lea=
rned from that /123 is an 'image processor' need not even come from the sam=
e server, you might have received it any number of ways. The server of that=
 /123 resource will not expect that you learned anything about this resourc=
e. It will just invoke the mapping function (the resource) based on the cur=
rent request.

There is no context and no shared understanding.

Jan






=
